discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Yellow

Explanation:
The Yellow Team is a relatively newer concept in cybersecurity testing that combines both defensive (Blue Team) and offensive (Red Team) methodologies. This team works with developers to securely build key applications and software by integrating security practices throughout the development lifecycle, also known as Secure Development Lifecycle (SDLC). Their focus is on proactively addressing vulnerabilities while also testing the application for security flaws from an attacker's perspective.

Why not the other options?
C. Red Team:
The Red Team conducts offensive testing by simulating real-world attacks to identify vulnerabilities and weaknesses. They don't directly engage with developers to build secure applications; they focus on penetration testing and exploitation.

While troubleshooting a firewall configuration, a technician determines that a “deny any” policy should be added to the bottom of the ACL. The technician updates the policy, but the new policy causes several company servers to become unreachable.
Which of the following actions would prevent this issue?

choices.D: Including an “allow any” policy above the “deny any” policy
choices.B: Testing the policy in a non-production environment before enabling the policy in the production network
choices.A: Documenting the new policy in a change request and submitting the request to change management
choices.C: Disabling any intrusion prevention signatures on the “deny any” policy prior to enabling the new policy

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Federation is primarily used for enabling single sign-on (SSO) and identity management across multiple systems, domains, organizations, etc. 

User provisioning tools (e.g., Azure AD, Okta, OneLogin, Ping Identity, IAM system, etc.) can automate the process.

Selected Answer: C
User provisioning is the process of automating the creation, modification, management, and removal of user accounts and permissions. It allows administrators to manage large-scale permission changes efficiently, as they can use automated workflows, tools, or scripts to make changes across many user accounts simultaneously. If the administrator wants to automate account permissions updates, user provisioning solutions (such as identity management platforms) would be the ideal tool.

Why A. Security groups is less correct:
While security groups help in grouping users with similar roles or permissions, they don't directly automate the update of permissions. Security groups make it easier to manage permissions for users who belong to the same group, but they don't automate the process for multiple accounts.

Selected Answer: C
Why the other options are less correct:
A. Security groups: Security groups are used to manage permissions for a group of users. While helpful, security groups themselves do not automate the process of updating permissions.
B. Federation: Federation involves enabling Single Sign-On (SSO) or linking identities across multiple systems but does not directly handle automated permissions updates.
D. Vertical scaling: Vertical scaling refers to increasing system resources (e.g., CPU, memory) to improve performance and has no relevance to account permissions.
